document_title: Gastrointestinal bleeding: Causes, symptoms, treatment, prevention
subsection_content:
1. Is gastrointestinal bleeding dangerous?
Gastrointestinal bleeding is a condition with many potential risks such as the risk of choking on blood (if there is a lot of bleeding) which can cause brain death and rapid death. Gastrointestinal bleeding can also be a sign of a certain type of digestive cancer. Therefore, this is a dangerous condition, patients need to be examined and treated as soon as possible.
2. Can gastrointestinal bleeding heal on its own?
As mentioned above, patients with upper gastrointestinal bleeding (high) can heal on their own within one to two weeks, depending on the severity. However, specific treatment interventions are needed to avoid complications or recurrence.
To schedule an examination and treatment for gastrointestinal bleeding with experienced experts of Tam Anh General Hospital System, please contact: Tam Anh General Hospital System: Hanoi: 108 Hoang Nhu Next, Bo De Ward, Long Bien District, Hanoi City Hotline: 024 3872 3872 – 024 7106 6858“>024 3872 3872 – 024 7106 6858 HCMC: 2B Pho Quang, Ward 2, Tan Binh District, HCMC Hotline: 0287 102 6789 – 093 180 6858“>0287 102 6789 – 093 180 6858 Fanpage: Tam Anh General Hospital Website: https://tamanhhospital.vn
3. After treatment, will gastrointestinal bleeding recur?
Gastrointestinal bleeding is very easy to recur, so after treatment, patients need to continue treatment, re-examine and carefully maintain their digestive tract to avoid recurrence.
Gastrointestinal bleeding should be considered a serious condition because it carries many worrying risks such as digestive cancer. Therefore, when there are signs of gastrointestinal bleeding such as bloody stools, black stools, bloody toilet paper, etc., patients should immediately go to the hospital for examination to detect potential problems early and receive timely treatment. . Currently, modern digestive endoscopy can help examine the digestive tract, detect lesions early and treat them. The earlier digestive diseases are treated, the more effective they are and vice versa, especially digestive cancers.
